Question_1.Context: Halide perovskite quantum dots (PQDs) are nanoparticles that have shown promise in optoelectronic applications due to their optical and electrical properties. However, they are known to have poor structural stability when exposed to external stimuli such as moisture and heat.
Question_1.Question: What is the main cause of structural degradation in halide perovskite quantum dots (PQDs)?
Question_1.B: Defect formation on the surface and vacancy formation in the lattices
Question_1.Source: The structural degradation of PQDs is primarily caused by the formation of defects (vacancies and interstitials) through ion migration and the detachment of weakly bound ligands on the PQD surface.

Question_2.Context: In the context of improving the structural stabilities of halide perovskite quantum dots (PQDs), various strategies have been developed. One such strategy involves modifying the ligands attached to the surface of PQDs.
Question_2.Question: Which strategy for improving the structural stability of PQDs involves changing the surface ligands?
Question_2.Source: The structural stabilities of PQDs can be improved through four methods: (1) ligand modification, (2) core–shell structure, (3) crosslinking, and (4) metal doping.

Question_3.Context: In the field of optoelectronics, core–shell structures are used to enhance the stability of materials. For PQDs, this involves coating the quantum dots with another material.
Question_3.Question: What is the purpose of introducing a core–shell structure to PQDs?
Question_3.C: To improve structural stability against external stimuli
Question_3.D: To reduce the overall size of the quantum dots
Question_3.Source: Core–shell structure: Polymers or inorganic materials are introduced as passivation layers to improve the structural stabilities of PQDs against external stimuli (moisture or oxygen).

Question_4.Context: Crosslinking is a method used to enhance the stability of PQDs by creating bonds between ligands on the surface of the quantum dots.
Question_4.Question: What is the main benefit of crosslinking the surface ligands of PQDs?
Question_4.A: To increase the quantum dot size
Question_4.C: To suppress ligand dissociation and minimize defect formation
Question_4.D: To change the color of the emitted light
Question_4.Source: Crosslinking: Crosslinkable ligands are introduced as surface passivation ligands to minimize defect formation by inhibiting ligand dissociation through the crosslinking of ligands via light or heat.

Question_5.Context: Metal doping in PQDs is a strategy used to enhance their structural stability by incorporating metal ions into the quantum dot lattice.
Question_5.Question: What is the effect of metal doping on the structural stability of PQDs?
Question_5.A: It decreases the migration energy of ions within the lattice
Question_5.B: It increases the photoluminescence quantum yield
Question_5.C: It changes the B–X bond lengths and improves stability
Question_5.D: It reduces the overall optical bandgap of the PQDs
Question_5.Source: Metal doping: Metal ions with equivalent charge numbers are doped at the A– or B–sites, which significantly improves the structural stabilities of PQDs by changing the B–X bond lengths.

Question_6.Context: The stability of PQDs is often tested by their response to external stimuli such as moisture, heat, and light. These tests help determine the effectiveness of various stabilization strategies.
Question_6.Question: Which external stimulus is known to cause poor structural stability in PQDs due to their ionic nature?
Question_6.Source: PQDs are easily decomposed or degraded under external stimuli (moisture, oxygen, and heat, etc.)

Question_7.Context: The optoelectronic properties of PQDs, such as photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY), are crucial for their performance in devices. Structural stabilities of PQDs are essential for maintaining high PLQY.
Question_7.Question: What happens to the photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) of PQDs when they undergo structural degradation?
Question_7.A: The PLQY increases due to enhanced light absorption
Question_7.B: The PLQY remains unchanged but the color spectrum shifts
Question_7.C: The PLQY decreases due to increased non-radiative recombination
Question_7.D: The PLQY oscillates due to fluctuating energy levels
Question_7.Source: This structural degradation increased non-radiative recombination and reduced the PLQY.

Question_8.Question: In the chemical structure of PQDs, where do the A-site cations and B-site cations reside?
Question_8.A: A-site cations at the face-center and B-site cations at the corners
Question_8.B: A-site cations at the corners and B-site cations at the body-center
Question_8.C: A-site cations at the edges and B-site cations at the face-center
Question_8.D: A-site cations at the body-center and B-site cations at the edges

Question_9.Question: How can the optical bandgap of PQDs be tuned to achieve different colors?
Question_9.A: By altering the size of the quantum dots
Question_9.B: By controlling the halide composition (Cl, Br, and I)
Question_9.C: By changing the temperature during synthesis
Question_9.D: By applying different voltages in the device
Question_9.Source: The optical bandgap (electroluminescence (EL) and photoluminescence (PL) emission) of the PQDs can be easily tuned by controlling the halide composition (Cl, Br, and I) to achieve full colors of blue, green, and red.
